explanation: The statement “(void) toe;” is the common idiom to explicitly mark a parameter as unused and to suppress compiler warnings. Although it is an expression-statement with no runtime side-effects (so, in a literal reading, removing it would not change the program’s runtime behaviour), MISRA’s prohibition on “dead code” is intended to avoid unreachable or leftover logic that masks faults — not to ban deliberate no-op annotations used to document or suppress warnings. In practice this idiom is an accepted way to indicate an intentionally unused parameter; if a project wishes to avoid such statements it can use a standardized UNUSED(x) macro or other documented mechanism, but the mere presence of “(void) toe;” in this callback is not a substantive MISRA Rule 2.2 violation in the sense that the rule is meant to address. Therefore the report that this line constitutes a Rule 2.2 violation is not correct.
